text: brains evolved in order to make bodies
move around in the world the body the
animal move around in the world and
interact with the objects in in that
world in order to improve its chances of
survival and reproduction that's really
fundamentally what brains are for so if
we try and simulate simulate the brain
and try and understand it and try and
build models of it in this disembodied
way I think that's the wrong way to go
so from the perspective of a computer
scientist and a roboticist what we need
to do is not just build a computer model
of the brain but we need to embody that
computer model so effectively that means
trying to build robots and make your
models control robots and make robots
move around in the world and interact
with things and we'll see an example of
that in the in the next video which is
due to Tony Prescott from the University
of Sheffield and colleagues from the
from the University of Bristol now this
this robot which is called shrew bot now
you can see that this robot which is
slightly scary has got whiskers and and
it's the latest in in a generation of a
series of robots that produced by this
group where they were studying whiskers
so they had a kind of rat but before
this and they discovered some very
interesting things so they were
interested in the rat barrel cortex so
that's a little bit of the rats cortex
which is to do with processing the
sensory information that comes in from
from whiskers and what they really quite
convincingly showed was that you cannot
understand a bit of rat barrel cortex by
studying it in vitro studying it in
isolation from the signals that are
coming in from these actual whiskers and
in the context of a big sensory motor
loop whereby the the whiskers touch
things and that and then the sensory
information comes from the whiskers as
they brush against things and then that
causes the rats to change the way its
whisking so if it touches something so
if the rat is
whisking away like this and it touches
something was that a good impersonation
of raps and it's and it touches
something on this side of its body then
it will change the way its whisking on
that side of the body in order to try
and sense more accurately exactly what's
going on there and that's all part of
the big sensory motor circuit and in
order to really understand what the all
of those nerves what those neurons are
doing in a context like that work any
context you've really got to understand
that whole sensory motor loop so if
we're going to try and build computer
models of the brain then I think we
really need to to embody them in robots
Chico
